Looking backwards to that year 2002 when "Furia" was made, one can easily recognize the heralding sings of today's New Generation in Romania. Comedians like Alina Pușcău, a veteran of Romanian Comedy TV or Andreea Bălan and her Cuc Arde In Vara crew were huge successes by that time. They brought all the group into the public's attention and this work still works perfectly in today's climate.

Leland follows the story of Leland P. Fitzgerald (Ryan Gosling), a disaffected teenager who has apparently murdered a severely retarded peer, the brother of his would-be lover and mentally unstable classmate Laura (Rachel McAdams). This is essentially a story about young love so the focus is definitely on the turmoil and tribulations of complex and often ambiguous relationships. This is a compelling, troubling, and ultimately a poetic film.
It is a labor of love. Four

This movie is a piece of the time in which it was made..... Realistic. Movies were not candy coated during the late 60s and early 70s. They were very "in touch" with what was going on because of how expressive and free they were. Granted movies like "Madhouse" are a bit "outthere" looking in 2005 but they make sense and give the viewer a bit of a new take on the old Scream Factor.

What other movies have you used soundtrack scores to give off meaning?

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. Centered on Miyazawa’s own life, this film depicts his adolescence through the lens of the ideals of agriculture and technology that his family had supported. Childhood days spent on the farm, innocent boys’ love, war, discord, suffering, weakness, sins, business collapse, and disorder are all beautifully intermingled

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The cat, whom Alice is going to kill, comes back as a man, has sex with her, and turns everyone around town into cats to stop Alice from killing him.
